body:
LGTM. Merge to master and branch-0.7 if no further discussions.

Thanks @VipinRathor for the contribution!

Agree with this @felixcheung , linux permission mode : `read + write + execute` seems more suitable and understandable. We should be very careful to deliver this kind of feature, because once we deliver it, it is better not to change it for keeping compatibility and user experience.

`provide an environment variable to tell Zeppelin where is the notebook dir. The variable should be prior to configs in zeppelin-site.xml (regardless of this pr, this would be nice feature for dockerization)
`
You can use set env varaible `ZEPPELIN_CONF_DIR` for that.
LGTM merge if no more discussion.

@zjffdu it would have been a good idea to do that but rights on zeppelin are different than rights on a Unix system. For example, a user that has write permission can write, read and execute the note. So the rights are not properly isolated and I think this should bring another type of discussion to whether isolate the rights or not in order to make it more similar to a Unix system

Do we have something like ldapADGCRealm.userLowerCase which will force username to change the case to lower. Currently if i set user permission to "user1" and then i login with "User1", i cannot see the notebooks.
@zjffdu what's the benefit of *not* doing it, given it's a simple change?
@1ambda Could you please check my comment above?

@herval This is an improvement PR, not bug fix PR. And based on the discussion above, it may also introduce some other issues or overhead for users (e.g. some interpreters don't support scala 2.11).
Besides, after we move out interpreters from zeppelin project, scala version should not be an issue anymore. Let me know your concern and if I miss anything. Thanks
@sadhen would setting env variable `ZEPPELIN_CONF_DIR` to a folder out of docker image work for you ?

IMO introducing `EXECUTE` permission makes sense. For instance.

1. A shared notebook (dashboard) contains important indices and it requires large query executions. Thus I don't want to allow readers to change dynamic forms (dropdown). **It will be used only view-mode**

2. I have another notebook made for cooperation between UI team and developer team. the developer team wrote queries and UI team will change dynamic forms and execute queries for A/B testing. But the developer team also wants to allow a manager of the project sees the notebook to check the state of the project but the manager will be not able to execute.

for case (1), we need READ-ONLY permission.
for case (2). we need to support READ-ONLY + EXECUTE permissions.

**introducing `EXECUTE` permission gives Zeppelin users flexibility can be applied to multiple use cases**
@1ambda Thanks for clarfiying these scenarios.

@zjffdu 
It won't satisfy my need.

You may understand my concerns when you start dockerizing Zeppelin.

And these days, I encounter another dockerization problem. If I put interpreter and server processes all in one container, the interpreter process will run out of memory. My final solution is deploying interpreters elsewhere.

```
ERROR [2017-08-24 00:12:17,391] ({Thread-0} TThreadPoolServer.java[serve]:194) - ExecutorService threw error: java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
        at java.lang.Thread.start0(Native Method)
        at java.lang.Thread.start(Thread.java:714)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.addWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:950)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.execute(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1368)
        at org.apache.thrift.server.TThreadPoolServer.serve(TThreadPoolServer.java:168)
        at org.apache.zeppelin.interpreter.remote.RemoteInterpreterServer.run(RemoteInterpreterServer.java:104)
 INFO [2017-08-24 00:24:30,979] ({Thread-0} RemoteInterpreterServer.java[run]:103) - Starting remote interpreter server on port 40623
```

@1ambda @zjffdu 
Thank you for your comments. Classes have been renamed to match its functionality

Can you explain a bit more why setting `ZEPPELIN_CONF_DIR` to outside of docker image won't work for you ? I am not so familiar with docker, may need more context to understand that.

There's one in-progress PR to put conf folder in hdfs, would that work for you ?

There's another in-progress PR to support to run interpreter process in a separate machine.
@VipinRathor Can you please update the description from "Updated shiro.init.template ..." to "Updated shiro.ini.template ...".

I think this feature is useful.  That's because admin can't see all notes currently 

- since admin is not treated as owner by default even admin has `admin` role. 
- so admin needs to ask all notebook creators to add admin into the owner list as well.
- otherwise, the admin needs to find / modify every `note.json` to put their name.

IMO, it's quite weird and I think this PR can solve the problem.

@yu74n Could you solve the conflict and reply @felixcheung's last comment?

>  but seems like this isn't just default owner/admin for private mode only, but in all cases?

I have a question (regarding concurrency issue, I think other might help to review this one)

you said that 

>  I confirm the code I wrote for Zeppelin 0.6.0 solved the dead lock problem. 

Then, Is this PR for branch-0.6? or you confirmed that this even works for master? (0.8.0-SNAPSHOT)

ng-style would work. LGTM, merge if no more discussion.

Tests passed but build failed due to an irrelevant issue.

- https://travis-ci.org/SDRLurker/zeppelin/jobs/264653451
ping @Leemoonsoo @1ambda @felixcheung @prabhjyotsingh for review

No, this PR is for the master, we recently upgraded from 0.6.0 to master.

Still to be confirmed and verified. However, we are running my PR in production for over 50 analysts (we mainly use Zeppelin as a platform for analysts to write and run Spark SQL query). It works well.

And our QA has tested the PR using python to directly send websocket message with over 200 websocket connections.

@VipinRathor Also, I think it will be a good idea to mention an one-liner in the shiro.ini.template "Enable 'cookie.secure = true' only when Zeppelin is running on HTTPS" or something similar. 

If enabled when Zeppelin is running on HTTP, Browser does not set the cookie and hence user session won't be maintained.

@1ambda thx
@felixcheung You are right, this feature affects all modes(private and public). I don't understand public mode in detail, is there any problem if we set admin role in public mode? Should I set admin role at NotebookAuthorization.setNewNotePermissions() when a notebook is created?
Is it must to have threadpool for this deadlock issue ? Can it be solved in a more clean way like you did in #2465 ?
One more thing. Should we set admin role to notebook owner in public mode? I'm going to change this feature to set admin role to notebook owner, reader and writer in private mode though.

I used `optimize import` function from IntelliJ.
does import order can be the matter in this situation?

@krishna-pandey You are right. Setting "secure=true" in cookie will force cookie to travel only over HTTPS. When Zeppelin is running over HTTP, browsers won't send this 'secure' cookie back. So Zeppelin will generate new session id every time when a request is made, therefore user sessions will not be maintained. I've commented that line and added comment too.

@felixcheung Thanks for reviewing. Zeppelin, by default, should set 'HttpOnly' flag for all session cookies as security measure against XSS attacks. That's why we have decided to include that in shiro.ini.template as default setting.
Let me know if you have any concerns over this.
that is very nice
LGTM!

this is possible since this PR from @volumeint to bujiio:
https://github.com/bujiio/buji-pac4j/pull/63

Would like to hear about any further improvements required on this feature @felixcheung, @Leemoonsoo 

Thanks for your thoughts @Tagar
@1ambda @zjffdu @felixcheung do you still need clarifications or modifications from me?
@Leemoonsoo @jongyoul I will commit if no more comments so that I can continue the other work.
could you review my comments? there are a number of comments from before that I feel we should address first.
any more comment?
I will merge it if no more comments
@1ambda I have merged #2474, can you rebase this PR ? Thanks
Sorry, I found it conflicts with other PRs, will revert it now.
I don't see the alert in the original code? Could you point me to it?
Sure - feel free to close this and open a new PR.

https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/6bd6c70881e8515a5b0679e5a8d6c235cfb1adf6/zeppelin-web/src/components/navbar/navbar.controller.js#L104

I think that someone like @1ambda or @Leemoonsoo maybe can clarify and add it's opinion to decide if keep the pop-up or not (personally I do not care ...)
LGTM

Is it intended or work in progress?

regarding import order. Of course, it doesn't matter in the feature perspective.

- we want minimal change so that any reviewer (even for the beginner) can review easily.
- reviewers might be confused "why these irrelevant changes are included? There is something I am missing?"
- and we want not to include the irrelevant changes to prevent the side effect

@1ambda 
what about implementation like a Jetbrains Idea comparator?
1) header contains comboboxes for choice commit and combobox with mode of diff
  - side-by-side paragraph
  - side-by-side all paragraphs (join text of all paragraphs and compare)
2) actions block contains buttons (next paragraph with changes, prev paragraph with changes, next changes into current paragraph, prev changes into current paragraph, combobox with all paragraphs )
3) diff
Let me test this branch little more with some edge cases.

As it turns out, we do need to inherit from `object` in order to keep the class a new-style python class in python 2. I had mistakenly thought `StringIO.StringIO` was a new-style class, but turns out it is not.

There was another python2 problem I came across (`StringIO.StringIO` is missing the `encoding` attribute, which was needed).

I had attempted to have `Logger` extend `TextIOWrapper`, but this caused a lot of problems with python2's byte-based `str` class, and extending `BytesIO` caused problems in python3 due to their unicode-based strings.
@sctincman could you try restart a failed CI build job? https://travis-ci.org/sctincman/zeppelin/jobs/270477925 I think it's flaky test but just in case.

thanks we definitely need it to work for python 2 and 3.
could you also look into adding some tests - i think we have interpreter tests for python

The one of famous products what does the same thing with this PR is Source Tree as u know. And it has this kind of UI. I think @tinkoff-dwh you can get ideas from this UI

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4968473/29953291-dcf555ec-8f09-11e7-9bd2-3580fdb1bc1a.png)

- you can see the whole commit list and scroll down to navigate more. 
- if you click one commit, automatically display the diff between prev commit
- if you want to compare to separate commits explicit, you can select the commits for comparison.

feasibility ask: Like we support python2, and python3 do you think it makes sense to have 2 different interpreters (at-least for now) one that supports Livy-0.2.0/0.3.0 and other as Livy-4?

The reason I'm asking this is because what I see in this PR is, this PR is trying to download Livy-0.4.0 for integration/unit tests but most of the integration tests are turned off.

Thanks @zjffdu for great work.
LGTM

Actually this livy interprete support both livy 0.2.0 / 0.3.0 /0.4.0, because livy's rest api doesn't change, only its java package name changes. So I can not add integration test for both of these versions.

for example, Spark passes on `spark.hadoop.foo` as `foo` to hadoop/hive conf, which I think it's a better approach?

[here](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/d7b1fcf8f0a267322af0592b2cb31f1c8970fb16/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/deploy/SparkHadoopUtil.scala#L101) and [here](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/3f958a99921d149fb9fdf7ba7e78957afdad1405/sql/hive/src/test/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/hive/HiveUtilsSuite.scala#L41)

we could pass `zeppelin.spark.foo` as `foo` to Spark (and `spark.*`, assuming foo != spark)
hmm, seems a better approach. Update the PR
